history.content:
This is probably a question for the Math department and they will almost surely tell you that 54 is required. 

---------

The math department does in some cases allow you to get credit by examination.  I'm not sure if you can do that for the minor, but it might be worth asking your math adviser.  (If you do go with that strategy, keep in mind that 54 covers differential equations, which the 16AB series does not)

---------

Having taken 16A/B and Math 54, I would say 16A/B doesn't cover all topics to the depth I had when I took Math 54 (but this varies by Math professor, while 16A/B probably would be more consistent once it stabilizes).  I would correct the above student response and mention that 16B does cover differential equations quite a bit (but not as thorough as my 54 experience!).

This is probably a question for the Math department and they will almost surely tell you that 54 is required. 

---------

The math department does in some cases allow you to get credit by examination.  I'm not sure if you can do that for the minor, but it might be worth asking your math adviser.  (If you do go with that strategy, keep in mind that 54 covers differential equations, which the 16AB series does not)
This is probably a question for the Math department and they will almost surely tell you that 54 is required.

Hi everyone,

I'm an incoming EECS major, and I'm planning on pursuing a minor in Math. I know that I don't have to take Math 54 for my EECS requirements because EE 16A and 16B cover the material, but Math 54 is a requirement for a minor in Math. Does this mean I will have to take Math 54 if I want to do a Math minor?
history.subject: Math 54 for Math Minor?
